title: Influencing Policy for Adoption
description: Governments' and policy makers lack of use-case understanding of blockchain technology results in Country adoption friction

f6_assessments.q0: Educating more people on the ground in their own language is an absolute must for creating successful expansion of Cardano community hubs. If successful the people attending these events will tell people close to them about this and help educate more people about Cardano and how it could benefit their communities.
f6_assessments.q1: Already active and established team members in their communities and on Project Catalyst. The budget allocation and plan seems sensible. The timeline provided will enable them to do enough groundwork to ensure that these events have sufficient attendees. Will there be something attendees can take away from the event to show or educate their friends? Will there be a source of information they can go to after the event if they wanted to know something?
f6_assessments.q2: The solution they offer to scale up community hubs in these countries is to hold an event in each country. They will invite high profile government officials to attend these events to introduce and educate them about Cardano causing local community hubs to operate with the support of the government. They provided a clear roadmap with milestones and KPIs and a clear definition of success.  They considered the risks Covid will have on these meetings and are ready to address them should they arise. More info could be provided regarding the public attendance of these events. Are these events for high profile policy makers/government officials only or can the public also attend?

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal doesn't address the "average person" that can be a part of the local community. The proposal does address a "niche" of the local community, the policy makers, and the project aims to educate & onboard "100" on a local Cardano Hub. This number is highly optimistic, and the proposer doesn't provide clear details about the impact for the Cardano ecosystem based on the project goals', and the statement of what problem is to be solved remains vague. A good approach is to define exactly what community areas' could benefit from the Cardano ecosystem, if policy makers are involved (i.e: better/improved Education System, adoption of financial services using blockchain etc.). Some Key metrics don't have a target value set. For a better auditability the proposer should set values for the metrics (i.e. number of users downloading an ADA wallet in a time frame - 1000, number of users onboarding on WADA - 500 - also this metric seems to not have too much in common with the Cardano ecosystem, as WADA sustaining only blockchain technology)
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer provides evidence of skills and experience necessary to implement the proposal. Adding "+WADA team" as a team member for the project, is very vague and not clear with its role. The budget is broken down into identifiable items but is not very clear what each item incorporates (not clear what team costs meaning (salary, incentives etc.), not clear who the speaker is and why is to be given 1k (could be an influencer, a listened local community member, an average person etc.) what marketing instruments are to be used and why 3k are necessary - example: 15.000 flyers $200, TV spot for 3 appearances - $500, banners - 5 pieces - $700 etc.)

A timetable is offered for implementing the proposal but is somehow unrealistic in it's length as one year for this kind of activity (2 local meetings and outcome consolidation) seems to be too much. A 6 months period for implementing this proposal maybe will suffice.

Implementing such project in DR of Congo seems to be highly unlikely, because due to the highly risk of unrest and social disorder makes the political actors to be in unstable positions. This means that what the members of the project agree, this month, with the policy makers could not be viable after 3 months, taking into the consideration the time frame for implementing the proposal. The proposer hasn't consider all challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation. COVID-19 is a risk to be taken into consideration but with not a relevant impact for project implementation.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal has a roadmap but the time horizon seems to be unrealistic for what it will be necessary for implementing the proposal.
The proposal lacks some important information, such as estimates of content to be delivered (i.e. 5 policy makers, involved in the Educational System, onboarded, 5.000 attendees for the meetup etc.). Metrics to define the success of the proposal don't have an associated value and cannot be quantified. The description of the problem is not clearly identified. The solution is not clearly understandable and doesn't address a problem.

Given explicit details for the proposal will make it easier for an outsider to understand the made statement and for the community to have a better feasibility assessment and to understand the impact of the proposal.
f6_assessments.reply:
Confusing Impact Assessment Note:  The Assessor's note is a confusing mish mash of feasibility and auditability that doesn't really address whether or not the this proposal aligns or impacts the challenge question of this category. To show the Impact of this proposal, the proposal cleary indicates : "How does the proposal fit into this challenge?"
"Unfavorable government policies hamper blockchain adoption at the grassroot level. Creating a favorable blockchain policy climate ensures thriving local Cardano Community hubs 
"How will this campaign add value to our ecosystem?"
"The 'Scam' narrative in many African countries has lead to wholesale bans of cryptocurrencies and blockchain due to limited understanding of DLT usage and value.
Ensuring that Cardano adoption is driven at the ground level without fear of government reprisals, will empower people to change their lives, create ownership and expand Cardano market" Subjective Feasibility Note: In saying that organizing  a one day high profile event in DRC "seems highly unlikely due to risk of unrest and social disorder"  this Assessor makes false assumptions about local conditions that they feel will impact this project. Goma, the city that this event will be held in holds many high profile events every day and is a chosen site for hosting the upcoming Cardano Summit. The Assesors's note about the 1 year timeline for this project is inaccurate. This is a one day event. The outcomes is what will be monitored over a span of one year. Confusing Auditability Assessment Note; Again, this Assessor mixes up the auditability of this proposal with it's impact and didn't seem to have paid any attention to the metrics clearly outlined in the proposal or read the proposal overall.

f6_assessments.q0: Government and Policy Makers communities are in desperate need for better understanding of Blockchain technologies and how they impact Society I 'Strongly Agree' your proposal address the challenge of Scaling up Cardano's community Hubs
f6_assessments.q1:
Over 30 years as an IT Manager having to educate Business Executives on the benefits of Technology. I have reviewed your proposal, your team and your budget.

I feel your project goals are measured and attainable. Your team is experienced in reaching out into the communities and your budget is within reason. I 'Strongly Agree' you will be able to implement successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: More easily measured is the metrics on number of attendees at events, downloads of Wallets, and Memberships in WADA. What is not so easily measured is the impact on Government / Policy Maker Officials. It will be interesting to see how your report this effort back to the voting community. I 'Agree' your proposal is sufficient to audit.

f6_assessments.q0:
The idea is great and there is good value in such a proposal. However, I will content more directly between the proposal and the challenge. For example how those two events will help to support local hubs in Ghana and DCR (there are local hubs?) or develop new hubs. 

From the impact part of your proposal, it might fit another challenge? I.e. Grow Cardano, Grow Africa. In any event, connecting the events to the community hubs is missing in my view. 
 
Also, did you consider additional follow-up events or other ideas to have an ongoing relationship with policymakers?
f6_assessments.q1:
The references, organizations involved, team members, and knowledge of catalysts and Cardano all show high feasibility for a successful proposal. Plan vs. idea is aligned with clear next steps. 

Great that you put clear project leads with Linkedin links (check the LinkedIn link for DCR lead)

The budget is reasonable but I will add the time frame and more details for example in the case of the team cost, what is the period covered 6 months or 12 months?
f6_assessments.q2:
Well done for including the risks and challenges. 
Deliverables are clear as well as timeframe and roadmap. 
KPIs & Metrics are mentioned in general terms - for example, "more favorable view" - it is very difficult to measure it as a KPI. Also, how do measure the impact of the event on new members' KPI? Or how do you measure engagement? It would have been good to specify it more with some clear numbers. 
I would also add specific targets for the KPI of numbers of Attendees (you mentioned 100 in previous sections), and Attendees onboarded into WADA memberships. 

In my view, the proposal does not give a clear connection between the event and the key KPIs of the specific challenge.
